text: “The more time I spent with my father-in-law’s books, the more profoundly they seemed to be not revealing him but hiding him, like some word-wreathed, untranslatable mausoleum.” https://t.co/3jG7220kyg

text: The fast-food workers featured in Richard Renaldi’s photographs are “people that millions of Americans see every day—but, at the same time, they’re invisible, because a lot of low-wage labor isn’t appreciated and is taken for granted,” he said. https://t.co/vUIkdD755g

text: For music, time is space, and Sonny Rollins is a virtual landscape artist, one who sees panoramically and travels extensively through the musical realm of his time. https://t.co/dj1Mo42qwQ

name: NewYorker
text: With an end to the coronavirus pandemic in sight, our job is to get everyone around us safely there: it was devastatingly sad that people died of COVID-19 last March, but such deaths would be tragic in a different way this March, @BillMcKibben writes. https://t.co/PZoLYzkZej

text: Inertia and vested interest are the main reasons our energy systems have been slow to change, even though rapid climate change represents the ultimate in imaginable violence, injustice, and chaos. https://t.co/0Unv62FF8f

text: In August, the Big Ten Conference announced that it was postponing its season until the spring. College football players had begun returning to practice in June, and team after team around the country had suffered outbreaks of SARS-CoV-2. https://t.co/eBHyXMSo1j

name: NewYorker
text: “The space inside a television is familiar yet alien, like one of those dreams of being in your house but the house isn’t your house,” David Gilbert writes, in a new Personal History. “It is uncanny.” https://t.co/zDIMDlxWTi
